content:
Introduction

Fetal growth restriction (FGR) is the pathologic failure of a fetus to reach its growth potential.  FGR is diagnosed when the ultrasonographic estimated fetal weight (EFW) or abdominal circumference is <10th percentile for a given gestational age.  FGR is associated with increased perinatal morbidity and mortality; therefore, impacted pregnancies require close surveillance to minimize the risk for adverse outcomes.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



FGR results from various placental, maternal, or fetal factors that lead to abnormal growth.  FGR is classified as either symmetric or asymmetric, which varies depending on the timing and type of initial insult (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).

Symmetric fetal growth restriction



Symmetric FGR is uniform and equal global growth impairment (eg, head, femur, abdomen); it begins in the first trimester and/or early second trimester due to an early developmental insult (eg, aneuploidy, congenital infection) that affects cell number and overall growth.  Causes of symmetric FGR include:



  • Congenital (TORCH [Toxoplasmosis, Other infections, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus infection, Herpes simplex]) infection (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  Such infections cause an obliterative angiopathy of vessels, decreasing blood flow to the fetus.
  • Chromosomal abnormalities (eg, trisomies, monosomy X):  Chromosomal abnormalities disrupt the genetic signals needed for proper fetal growth and placental function.
  • Multiple gestation (
    figure 1
    ):  Monochorionic pregnancies are at risk for unbalanced arteriovenous anastomoses within the shared placenta, which results in reduced blood flow and growth restriction within one fetus.
  • Substance use (eg, tobacco, cocaine) and teratogen exposure.
  • Isolated structural abnormalities.

Asymmetric fetal growth restriction



Asymmetric FGR is disproportionate growth impairment due to uteroplacental insufficiency that leads to chronic fetal hypoxia.  Uteroplacental insufficiency affects nutrient and oxygen delivery and most often develops during the late second trimester or third trimester.  The fetus adapts to decreased nutrients/oxygen by prioritizing blood flow to critical organs (eg, brain) and away from noncritical organs (eg, abdomen).  This creates unequal growth restriction with a relatively normal head size and a disproportionately smaller abdomen (ie, head-sparing growth lag).  Causes of asymmetric FGR include:



  • Maternal vascular disease (eg, pregestational diabetes mellitus, antiphospholipid-antibody syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus):  Maternal vascular disease impairs placental development and restricts placental blood flow.
  • Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (eg, preeclampsia, gestational hypertension):  Poor spiral artery formation at the time of trophoblast invasion reduces placental function and perfusion (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Placental disorders (eg, abruption, infarction) and umbilical cord anomalies (eg, single umbilical artery, marginal cord insertion):  Placental disorders can reduce fetal blood flow with a resultant decrease in nutrient and oxygen delivery.
  • Poor maternal nutrition:  An extremely low protein intake or severe calorie restriction (ie, intake of 600-900 kcal daily) can result in insufficient nutrients to support fetal growth.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



FGR is diagnosed via transabdominal ultrasonography using fetal measurements of the head (both head circumference and biparietal diameter), abdominal circumference, and femur length.  Restricted growth is diagnosed when the overall EFW or the isolated abdominal circumference measurement is <10th percentile.  If the EFW or abdominal circumference is below the 3rd percentile, FGR is considered severe, which is associated with higher risks for adverse outcomes.



FGR may be diagnosed incidentally (eg, ultrasonography performed for other reasons) or when fundal height is smaller than expected for gestational age (

Measuring fundal height
).  Following a diagnosis of FGR, all patients undergo a more detailed fetal anatomy ultrasonography, and additional evaluation is dependent on the type of growth restriction.



Symmetric FGR evaluation typically includes genetic testing (eg, karyotype analysis, microarray) and TORCH viral titers, particularly if there is a history of infection or abnormal fetal ultrasonographic findings.  Asymmetric FGR evaluation typically includes maternal blood pressure (eg, preeclampsia, gestational hypertension), weight gain, and nutritional status.  Additional evaluation (eg, antiphospholipid antibodies) is typically more tailored based on prior obstetric or medical history.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of FGR includes other conditions that can lead to the fetus measuring smaller than anticipated on ultrasonography; these include:



  • Constitutionally small fetus (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Fetuses are small due to genetic potential (ie, small parents) with no underlying pathology.  Fetal constitutional smallness is associated with short maternal stature, low prepregnancy weight, and fetal female sex.  Constitutional smallness presents with an EFW or abdominal circumference <10% for gestational age, normal umbilical artery Doppler (UAD) evaluation, and appropriate interval growth.
  • Incorrect pregnancy dating:  Because the diagnosis of FGR is based on the growth percentile for a certain gestational age, fetuses may falsely appear small if gestational age is incorrect.

Management



FGR management is based on antenatal surveillance, which is performed to reduce the risk for poor outcomes (eg, intrauterine fetal demise) while allowing time for maximum fetal growth in utero.  This involves several surveillance tests.

Serial growth ultrasonography



Serial growth ultrasonography is performed every 3-4 weeks to evaluate interval growth because poor interval growth may be an indication for earlier delivery.

Umbilical artery Doppler ultrasonography



UAD ultrasonography is used to evaluate the vascular resistance of blood flow from the fetus to the placenta.  UADs in growth-restricted pregnancies reflect placental function and are predictive of fetal oxygenation and perinatal morbidity and mortality.



Normally, the placenta is characterized by high-perfusion, low-resistance vessels.  This leads to forward (toward the fetus) umbilical artery blood flow throughout the entire maternal cardiac cycle (even maternal diastole), which allows for continuous delivery of oxygen and nutrients.  However, in pregnancies with uteroplacental insufficiency, arterial resistance compromises blood flow, leading to poor oxygen and nutrient delivery.  Progressive arterial resistance is seen and monitored with UADs and generally occurs in a stepwise fashion:



  • Elevated systolic/diastolic (S/D) ratio:  With the initial arterial impedance, there is decreased forward flow during diastole compared to systole, resulting in an elevated S/D ratio.
  • Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF):  As arterial resistance worsens, there is absent blood flow through the umbilical artery during maternal diastole.
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow (rEDF):  in the most severe cases, arterial resistance is so high that blood flows in the reverse direction (ie, away from the fetus) during diastole.


The progression of UAD findings mirrors the severity of placental insufficiency and the risk for intrauterine fetal demise.  Therefore, UADs are performed weekly in growth-restricted fetuses to monitor placental function, which guides delivery planning.

Additional fetal testing



In addition to UADs and serial growth ultrasonography, routine antenatal testing is performed to monitor fetal well-being.  These include:



  • Biophysical profiles (BPPs):  Ultrasonography is used to evaluate amniotic fluid and fetal activity (eg, tone, movement), which are indicators of fetal renal perfusion, acid-base status, and oxygenation.
  • Nonstress testing (NST):  NST evaluates fetal acid-base status based on heart rate monitoring.


Normal antenatal testing (eg, reactive NST, normal BPP) suggests a low risk for intrauterine fetal demise within a week of the test date.  In contrast, abnormal findings may necessitate immediate intervention (eg, delivery).

Delivery timing and planning



The optimal timing of delivery is based on the underlying etiology of growth restriction, gestational age, and clinical findings.  Delivery is recommended when the risks for intrauterine demise with continued in utero growth exceed the risks for prematurity.



General guidelines are as follows:



  • EFW/abdominal circumference between the 3rd and 10th percentile:  38-39 weeks gestation.
  • Severe FGR (EFW/abdominal circumference <3%) with an elevated S/D ratio:  37 weeks gestation.
  • AEDF:  33-34 weeks gestation.
  • rEDF:  30-32 weeks gestation.


In preterm gestations, magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection at deliveries <32 weeks gestation, as well as antenatal corticosteroids (eg, betamethasone) for fetal lung maturity at deliveries <34 weeks gestation, should be administered.



FGR alone is not an indication for cesarean delivery.  However, fetuses with growth restriction (particularly with abnormal UADs) are at increased risk for cesarean delivery due to fetal intolerance of labor from uteroplacental insufficiency (seen as late decelerations).

Prognosis



FGR is a term used during pregnancy.  Following delivery, neonates <10th percentile for gestational age at delivery are referred to as small for gestational age (SGA).  Overall, the prognosis depends on the underlying etiology, the severity of FGR (and UAD-visualized abnormalities), and the gestational age at which delivery is required (ie, prematurity risk).  FGR and SGA infants are at risk for both short- and long-term complications.



Short-term complications include:



  • Polycythemia:  Chronic hypoxia induces increased erythropoietin and red blood cell expansion.
  • Hypoglycemia:  Chronic nutrient deprivation results in lower plasma glucose and insulin concentrations, leading to decreased liver and muscle glycogen stores.
  • Hypothermia:  Shunting blood to vital organs decreases subcutaneous fat and increases heat loss.
  • Hypocalcemia:  Placental dysfunction decreases calcium transfer to the fetus.
  • Perinatal asphyxia and meconium aspiration:  Growth-restricted infants have a difficult respiratory transition following birth and may experience hypoxic events leading to organ damage; placental dysfunction can cause intrauterine stress during labor and increase the likelihood of meconium-stained fluid.


Long-term complications include:



  • Delayed cognitive development and motor dysfunction.
  • Behavioral issues (eg, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder).
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Childhood obesity and metabolic syndrome.

Prevention



Because not all causes of FGR can be prevented, strategies are focused on mitigating modifiable risk factors.  Preconception visits and routine prenatal care help identify risk factors, optimize maternal health, and allow for early FGR surveillance.  All patients should be counseled on a healthy, well-balanced diet and appropriate weight gain during pregnancy.  In addition, tobacco cessation and active management of substance use disorders should be discussed.  Maternal conditions with increased FGR risk (eg, hypertension, pregestational diabetes mellitus, systemic lupus erythematosus) should be controlled prior to pregnancy.

Summary



Fetal growth restriction (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) is defined as an estimated fetal weight or abdominal circumference at <10th percentile for gestational age and is classified as either symmetric (global growth lag) or asymmetric (head-sparing growth lag).  Etiologies can include chromosomal abnormalities, congenital infection, and uteroplacental insufficiency (eg, preeclampsia, diabetes mellitus).  Because of the increased risk for intrauterine fetal demise, patients with fetal growth restriction require increased antepartum surveillance and early delivery.
